file_name: BOLIVARMININGCORP_05_23_2003-EX-2.1-VISP WEB SITE BUILDING AND HOSTING AGREEMENT.txt

perturbation.original_text: This Agreement is made on this 12th day of May 2003 by and between YourNetPlus.com, Inc., a New York Corporation; with its principle office located at 501 Route 208, Monroe, NY 10950 ("Provider") and Kingdom Connect, Inc., a Corporation with its principle office located at 1045 Stephanie Way, Minden, NV 89423 ("KCI").
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement is made on this 12th day of May 2003 by and between YourNetPlus.com, Inc., a New York Corporation; with its principle office located at 501 Route 208, Monroe, NY 10950 ("Provider") and Kingdom Connect, Inc., a Corporation with its principle office located at 1045 Stephanie Way, Minden, NV 89423 ("Client").
perturbation.explanation: The term 'KCI' is initially defined as 'Provider', but in a later section of the contract, it is referred to as 'Client'. This creates confusion as to which entity bears the responsibilities of each.

perturbation.original_text: KCI's Customers will receive an initial VISP web site setup including 5Mbs of storage space, maintenance of the site, technical support, and any services necessary for use of the site for no charge.
perturbation.changed_text: Client's End Users will receive an initial VISP web site setup including 5Mbs of storage space, maintenance of the site, technical support, and any services necessary for use of the site for no charge.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'KCI's Customers' to 'Client's End Users' creates an inconsistency. It is unclear if KCI's customers are the same as 'Client's End Users'. This may change the responsibilities of Provider in delivering the VISP web site setup.

perturbation.original_text: Seven hundred fifty thousand (750,000) shares of Kingdom Connect, Inc. Series A Preferred Stock.  Such stock issued assuming ten million (10,000,000) shares total issued and outstanding and to be adjusted accordingly to represent the same percentage should a different number be outstanding.  Once the common stock has been registered, or, after the one year period applicable under Rule 144, whichever occurs first, the Company at its sole cost and expense have its attorney issue an opinion letter for removal of the legend and release all stock transfer instructions on the common stock, except as maybe required under Rule 144. In the event the Company fails to have its attorney issue the required opinion letter within 20 days of a written request from YourNetPlus.com or its nominee, the Company shall be liable for liquidated damages in the amount of 10% interest per 30 days on the value of the shares based on the closing bid price of the Company's common stock on the 20th business day following the date it receives written notice from YourNetPlus.com or their nominee. The damages shall accrue until the transfer agent receives the opinion letter
perturbation.changed_text: Seven hundred fifty thousand (750,000) shares of Kingdom Connect, Inc. Series A Preferred Stock.  Such stock issued assuming ten million (10,000,000) shares total issued and outstanding and to be adjusted accordingly to represent the same percentage should a different number be outstanding.  Once the common stock has been registered, or, after the one year period applicable under Rule 144, whichever occurs first, the Business at its sole cost and expense have its attorney issue an opinion letter for removal of the legend and release all stock transfer instructions on the common stock, except as maybe required under Rule 144. In the event the Business fails to have its attorney issue the required opinion letter within 20 days of a written request from YourNetPlus.com or its nominee, the Business shall be liable for liquidated damages in the amount of 10% interest per 30 days on the value of the shares based on the closing bid price of the Company's common stock on the 20th business day following the date it receives written notice from YourNetPlus.com or their nominee. The damages shall accrue until the transfer agent receives the opinion letter
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'Company' with 'Business' without clarifying if they refer to the same entity creates ambiguity. The original text refers to the issuing company of the stock, but the change implies a different entity is responsible for actions regarding the stock. This could affect liability regarding the issuance and transfer of the stock.
